happens so mainly there are three parties involved of course you have the contactless card you have the point of sale terminal and of course the bank who
needs to approve the transaction so the interesting thing about uh using EMV is that you use the
chip that's inside the card so this way every transaction uh has dynamic uh
information so there's a crypto processor in the card that calculates uh and and encrypts data so that the bank
actually knows that the data is fresh compared to when you use a magnetic stripe card the data is always the same
so a magnetic stripe card can be easily cloned or easily copied uh the chip cannot be copied because there's a
secret key in and the key is stored inside the secure element and it's really difficult to extract the key from
the secure element so this key is also known by the bank so it's a shared
symmetric key scheme so when the card enters the proximity of the reader uh the protocol
starts and it begins with a handshaking and negotiation phase where the terminal and the card start to agree on what
protocol to use uh and yeah you know the the account number and things like
that so if everything is fine terminal will send a request to the card to please encrypt some of the transaction
details for example the amount and the currency the date they need to be encrypted by the card and the card then
uses its uh secret key uh to create an application cryptogram as it's called so it's just an encryption of the
transaction details but the terminal cannot decrypt it because the terminal does not have the the secret key so the
terminal actually forwards this cryptogram to the bank which does have the secret key so it can decrypt the
application cryptogram and it can verify if the details of the transaction are the same as the the point of sale
terminal claims they are so the bank has three options then it can either approve the transaction it
can reject transaction but it can also ask for another verification for example the
pin code so if the transaction is below €25 or below $25 it will be uh approved
but if it's above that amount uh an additional pin code is needed so the customer would end enter its pin code on
the terminal uh send to the bank and then the bank can either approve or reject the
transaction so if the transaction succeeds you will get a receipt of course from the from the terminal and if
you're really lucky sometimes on the receipt the application cryptogram is printed uh it's fun for me to see but
actually it's quite useless for most people uh so today we'll be focusing on the NFC
communication because the NFC communication is unencrypted for the most part while the the communication

communication is completely plain text so you can actually see what happens you can inject messages you can alter
messages you can do a lot so let's talk about relay attacks so

and back again so if you do this sophisticated enough the card won't know it is not communicating directly to the
terminal and the terminal will not know it's not directly communicating with the card so I'll now show you a short video
